Issues.Title: Additional changes to define Value property of Setter as XAML content property
Issues.Body:
Fixes #84

Main PR #745 

## Description

This PR is required to make Setter as XAML content property work during xaml compilation. 

## Customer Impact

This will make `Value` the `ContentProperty` for Setter in order to make the code a bit less verbose.

## Regression

NA

## Testing

Internal testing done, no new failures encountered.

## Risk

This change will affect the xaml tree depth, will make changes in wpf test repo in order to ensure appropriate test coverage to accommodate this.

Issues.Title: Replace binary formatter
Issues.Body:
## Description

The Binary Formatter was initially developed prior to the comprehensive understanding of deserialization vulnerabilities as a significant threat.  As a result, the code doesn’t follow the modern practices. Due to the security vulnerability Binary formatter is considered obsolete. In .NET 9.0, the entire Binary formatter infrastructure will be removed from the product. 

Binary Reader and Writer can be used to read and write the primitive data types into binary data and does not have any security vulnerability. We are creating a safe handle ‘BinaryFormatWriter’ which handles all primitives, Enums, strings, arrays and lists of primitives, and other items before falling into the process of serialization/deserialization. For serialization/deserialization we will use Binary writer. This approach will allow us to disable Binary formatter for the primitive and some other cases. 
 To convert the object to binary data we call TryWriteFrameworkObject with a memory stream and the object.  
BinaryFormattedObject class is added to parse a binary formatted object from a stream. It used Binary reader to read from a stream.
This solution is similar as in WinForms
PR: https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/pull/9088
CC
@JeremyKuhne @lonitra 

![image](https://github.com/dotnet/wpf/assets/107022063/f18c9730-7c61-4030-b3eb-4fb42b2cc3d0)


## Customer Impact
 In .NET 9.0, the entire Binary formatter infrastructure will be removed from the product and it will become obsolete. If not resolved, this will lead to build failure in .NET9, potentially causing significant delays and setbacks. It has additional benefits of making applications more friendly to linker trimming.



## Regression

N/A

## Testing

Internal testing done.

## Risk

Low
There might be a few instances where this solution won't be effective. Currently, this PR includes all the primitive types and few more data types. The plan is to handle additional cases as feedback comes in.

Issues.Title: Full ItemSource iteration on ExtendSelection
Issues.Body:
https://github.com/dotnet/wpf/blame/4ae9e616402ba1128eb11fb075746ed9b2fd6269/src/Microsoft.DotNet.Wpf/src/PresentationFramework/System/Windows/Controls/DataGrid.cs#L4845

FullRow Extending Selection traverses all `ItemSources` from index 0 to `endIndex`, stacking the UI if the `ItemSource` contains a large number of items.

For example, there are more than 1,000,000 rows and the selection starts somewhere at the end of the datagrid. Colossal load on the ItemsSource. In my case, `ItemsSource` is a virtualised collection, so if an item was not in the collection, a request is sent to the database to load it. 

So I end up having to find a workaround, set `DataGrid.SelectionMode == Single`, and simulate `Extended` mode in my code.

Please, say, for what enumerator is here, and may it be fixed?
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Full ItemSource iteration on ExtendSelection" (#8531)

Issues.Title: .net 8: Crash in ItemsControlAutomationPeer using recycling
Issues.Body:
### Description

 last line below: recyclableWrapper.**Peer**  is null

```
protected override string GetNameCore()
{
  AutomationPeer wrapperPeer = GetWrapperPeer();
  string text = null;
  object item = Item;
  if (wrapperPeer != null)
  {
    text = wrapperPeer.GetName();
  }
  else if (item != null)
  {
    ItemsControlAutomationPeer itemsControlAutomationPeer = ItemsControlAutomationPeer;
    if (itemsControlAutomationPeer != null)
    {
      using RecyclableWrapper recyclableWrapper = itemsControlAutomationPeer.GetRecyclableWrapperPeer(item);
      text = recyclableWrapper.Peer.GetName();
    }
  }
```

this issue looks similar:
 https://github.com/dotnet/wpf/pull/7115

### Reproduction Steps

Create an ItemsControl utilizing Groups with Recycling

  <Grid>
    <ItemsControl VirtualizingStackPanel.IsVirtualizing="True"
                  VirtualizingStackPanel.VirtualizationMode="Recycling"
                  VirtualizingStackPanel.IsVirtualizingWhenGrouping="True"
                  ItemsSource="{Binding GroupedItems}"
                  Template="{StaticResource TemplateListTemplate}">
      <ItemsControl.ItemsPanel>
        <ItemsPanelTemplate>
          <VirtualizingStackPanel />
        </ItemsPanelTemplate>
      </ItemsControl.ItemsPanel>
      <ItemsControl.ItemTemplate>
        <DataTemplate>
          <Expander Header="{Binding GroupName}">
            <ListBox ItemsSource="{Binding Items}">
              <ListBox.ItemTemplate>
                <DataTemplate>
                  <TextBlock Text="{Binding}" />
                </DataTemplate>
              </ListBox.ItemTemplate>
            </ListBox>
          </Expander>
        </DataTemplate>
      </ItemsControl.ItemTemplate>
    </ItemsControl>
  </Grid>

### Expected behavior

Need a null check

### Actual behavior

Debugger reports exception

### Regression?

_No response_

### Known Workarounds

_No response_

### Impact

_No response_

### Configuration

_No response_

### Other information

_No response_

Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "[main] Update dependencies from dotnet/winforms" (#8523)

Issues.Title: Localized strings incorrectly replaced to English or keyboard shortcuts in the Scrollbar context menu (and maybe more)
Issues.Body:
### Description

When executing a WPF app on .NET Core/5/6/7/8 using a non-English system, the scrollbar context menu has some incorrect command names, which does not happen on .NET Framework 4.8. For example, "Page Up" remains in English in some languages including French, Italian, and more.

### Reproduction Steps

On a Windows environment set to one of the languages, including but not limited to: French, Italian, Spanish.
Open any WPF app running on .NET Core or .NET 5+, and right-click on a scrollbar to open its context menu (from a ListView as an example).

### Expected behavior

All menu items should be on the same language and consistent, like in .NET Framework 4.8.
![image](https://github.com/dotnet/wpf/assets/19519567/6cef8089-6c10-4e4c-a22c-f5aeeeed82de)
Above language shows the context menu in French.

### Actual behavior

But since .NET Core, in some languages (French, Italian), the menu items "Page Down" and "Page Up" still appear in English, whereas the others are in the correct language.
![image](https://github.com/dotnet/wpf/assets/19519567/079c39a1-a95d-45ab-bc11-8d55e53e6e91)

This can also be seen in the localized string resource files (such as https://github.com/dotnet/wpf/blob/main/src/Microsoft.DotNet.Wpf/src/PresentationFramework/Resources/xlf/Strings.fr.xlf ) and looking at string IDs starting with ScrollBar_ .

Moreover, the menu item "Top" is not translated in almost all languages, including
 * [Japenese](https://github.com/dotnet/wpf/blob/47cf91bf2e375466c9584967cf082b4fc3bcc6ab/src/Microsoft.DotNet.Wpf/src/PresentationFramework/Resources/xlf/Strings.ja.xlf#L4818)
 * [Russian](https://github.com/dotnet/wpf/blob/47cf91bf2e375466c9584967cf082b4fc3bcc6ab/src/Microsoft.DotNet.Wpf/src/PresentationFramework/Resources/xlf/Strings.ru.xlf#L4818), ...

In some languages [Spanish](https://github.com/dotnet/wpf/blob/d17750126f3b5aab8e3986ab78812eb12132781f/src/Microsoft.DotNet.Wpf/src/PresentationFramework/Resources/xlf/Strings.es.xlf#L4768), the menu items use keyboard shortcut abbreviations (e.g. AvPág instead of "Avanzar la página" I presume).


### Regression?

In .NET Framework 4.8, the menu items in the Scrollbar are correctly translated, but since .NET Core, depending on the language, some menu items either changed to English or uses the keyboard shortcut abbreviation (instead of the command sentence).

### Known Workarounds

N/A Needs fixes in the localized string resources.

### Impact

Confusion for people who don't know English.

### Configuration

I tested on both .NET 5 and the latest .NET 8.
Though all .NET versions from .NET Core to .NET 8 are impacted (at least since WPF became open-source).
OS: Windows 10 22H2 x64
Not specific to any platform.

### Other information

Note that the Scrollbar might not be the only area where this translation regression happened. When looking at the [commit history of the French text resources of PresentationFramework]( https://github.com/dotnet/wpf/commits/47cf91bf2e375466c9584967cf082b4fc3bcc6ab/src/Microsoft.DotNet.Wpf/src/PresentationFramework/Resources/xlf/Strings.fr.xlf), this issue was already present in its very first commit (that is ae1790531c3b993b56eba8b1f0dd395a3ed7de75 #720).
But in commit 9afa976db6618e4cd9a944d68149d70e0cbeea58, at an attempt at "fixing localization crashes with key gestures", the document [Documentation/localization_untranslated_strings.md](https://github.com/dotnet/wpf/blob/47cf91bf2e375466c9584967cf082b4fc3bcc6ab/Documentation/localization_untranslated_strings.md) was created and mentions the strings "PageUp" and "PageDown" as being affected. However it seems that during the fixing all strings containing "Page Up" (even with space) were accidently being changed, even those that were not related to the crash, including the scrollbar context menu. This is means that all strings that contained similar words to the keyboard shortcuts mentioned in the document in the English version would be "reset" to English everywhere, or to an keyboard shortcut for some reason.

The issue was already reported in issue #4367 for the Simplified Chinese localization, and it might have been fixed, but nobody has realised that all the other languages were also affected. However, I checked in the latest commit and the fix seems to have been reverted to the English "Page Up" again by commit ddbf5a86f3ca221014c97720b97e26cd19eb8c25.

It might be ideal to find the pre-opensource commit that caused the regression and restore the localization of all strings unrelated to the crash that that pre-opensource commit was attempting to fix.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Localized strings incorrectly replaced to English or keyboard shortcuts in the Scrollbar context menu (and maybe more)" (#8522)

Issues.Title: Incorrect touch point coordinates when running application on secondary screen with WM_Pointer enabled
Issues.Body:
### Description

I am reporting an issue where incorrect touch point coordinates are obtained when calling the GetStylusPoint methods within an application that is moved to a non-primary screen on a multi-screen device with WM_Pointer enabled.

This issue was initially discovered by my friend @kkwpsv. I borrowed a touch-enabled display and set it as a secondary screen. I then monitored the StylusMove event and used the GetStylusPoint method to get the touch point after the event was triggered. I observed that the coordinates of the touch points I obtained were incorrect.

Concerned that it might be an implementation issue on my part, I switched to using the default InkCanvas control. I noticed that the coordinates of the traces drawn by the InkCanvas control were also offset. I recorded the screen as shown below. I have two screens, the left one is the primary screen and the right one is the secondary touch screen. I resized the window of the simplest demo application containing the InkCanvas control to span both screens. Then, I drew lines on the secondary screen using touch and observed that the InkCanvas control drew traces at incorrect coordinates.

![触摸偏移](https://github.com/dotnet/wpf/assets/16054566/63c2ee4f-d7d4-44f3-871e-4a96fb59883f)


### Reproduction Steps

Steps to reproduce:

1. Enable WM_Pointer messages by `AppContext.SetSwitch("Switch.System.Windows.Input.Stylus.EnablePointerSupport", true)`
2. Add InkCanvas control in MainWindow
3. Run on a device with two screens, with the left screen set as the primary screen and the right screen as the touch screen

Please touch on the right screen, you can see that the coordinates of the traces drawn by the InkCanvas control are incorrect. Furthermore, you can monitor events like StylusMove and use methods like GetStylusPoint or GetIntermediateTouchPoints to get touch points, and you will see that the coordinates of the obtained touch points are incorrect.

And my demo code is https://github.com/lindexi/lindexi_gd/tree/8c16318d0599c47b2090feaf84e14a2444af829c/BenukalliwayaChayjanehall

### Expected behavior

We can get the right touch coordinates.

### Actual behavior

We will see that the coordinates of the obtained touch points are incorrect.

### Regression?

All

### Known Workarounds

Upon investigation by @kkwpsv, it was found that this issue is due to an error in the implementation of the GetOriginOffsetsLogical method in HwndPointerInputProvider.cs. In the GetOriginOffsetsLogical method, the PointToScreen method is directly used to calculate the relative coordinates of the origin. This calculation method is only correct when there is only one screen. In the case of multiple screens, it is necessary to subtract the top left corner of the DisplayRect of the screen where the window is located to get the expected origin value, which can then be used to convert the window coordinates to coordinates relative to the virtual screen.

https://github.com/dotnet/wpf/blob/c02ae411282aee43075153a0751ab121ac32e3a3/src/Microsoft.DotNet.Wpf/src/PresentationCore/System/Windows/InterOp/HwndPointerInputProvider.cs#L311-L337

Thanks to @kkwpsv for his fix. He has corrected the code and posted it at https://github.com/dotnet-campus/wpf/pull/9. I have merged his code for testing. I have tested and verified @kkwpsv's fix. After his fix, WPF with WM_Pointer enabled can correctly obtain touch point coordinates using the GetTouchPoint or GetStylusPoint methods.

You can download and experience the fixed version at https://www.nuget.org/packages/dotnetCampus.WPF.Resource/6.0.4-alpha07-test06 . The demo code that fixes this issue using the above version of the [package](https://www.nuget.org/packages/dotnetCampus.WPF.Resource/6.0.4-alpha07-test06) is available at https://github.com/lindexi/lindexi_gd/tree/893292f260c4570ff63e68b9e0a29052a187d0c6/BenukalliwayaChayjanehall

### Impact

This bug will affect all applications running on multiple touch displays that have WM_Pointer enabled.

### Configuration

All

### Other information

I will submit @kkwpsv's bug fix code to the WPF repository after more partners and devices have participated in the testing.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Incorrect touch point coordinates when running application on secondary screen with WM_Pointer enabled" (#8517)

Issues.Title: [FR] Add NumericUpDown
Issues.Body:
Hello,

I would like to request a feature for a NumericUpDown control. This is a common widget that allows users to enter and adjust numeric values using a textbox and arrows or the mouse wheel. It is available in other frameworks such as Qt (see https://doc.qt.io/qt-6/qdoublespinbox.html and https://doc.qt.io/qt-6/qspinbox.html).

I think this would be a useful addition to the graphics framework, as it would provide a more user-friendly and intuitive way to input numeric data. Currently, the only option is to use a textbox with a validator, which is not very convenient or elegant.

Thank you for your consideration and your hard work on this project.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "[FR] Add NumericUpDown " (#8512)

Issues.Title: Fix for GetXmlNamespaceMaps and SetXmlNamespaceMaps exception
Issues.Body:
Fixes #1583 

## Description
`XmlAttributeProperties.GetXmlNamespaceMaps` and `XmlAttributeProperties.SetXmlNamespaceMaps` were throwing `System.InvalidCastException`, as it was not able to cast object of type `System.Collections.Hashtable` to type `System.String`.

## Regression

NA

## Testing

Tests have been modified to work correctly.

## Risk

Low

Issues.Title: Issue with System.Environment.FailFast failure on release/6.0 branch (version 6.0.26)
Issues.Body:
I recently pulled the release/6.0 branch, specifically version 6.0.26, to build a private DEBUG version for my testing work. However, I encountered an issue where the application would fail due to System.Environment.FailFast. 

Here is the stack trace of the failure code:

```
Description: The application requested process termination through System.Environment.FailFast(string message).
Message: DependencyProperties can only be set on DependencyObjects
   at MS.Internal.Helper.CheckCanReceiveMarkupExtension(MarkupExtension markupExtension, IServiceProvider serviceProvider, DependencyObject& targetDependencyObject, DependencyProperty& targetDependencyProperty)
   at System.Windows.Data.BindingBase.ProvideValue(IServiceProvider serviceProvider)
   at Cvte.Windows.ResourceKeyBindingExtension.ProvideValue(IServiceProvider serviceProvider)
   at System.Windows.TemplateContent.TrySharingValue(DependencyProperty property, Object value, String parentName, XamlReader xamlReader, Boolean allowRecursive, Nullable`1& sharedValue)
   at System.Windows.TemplateContent.TrySharingProperty(XamlReader xamlReader, XamlType parentType, String parentName, FrugalObjectList`1 previousNamespaces, Nullable`1& sharedValue)
   at System.Windows.TemplateContent.ParseNode(XamlReader xamlReader, StackOfFrames stack, List`1 sharedProperties, Int32& nameNumber, Object& newValue)
   at System.Windows.TemplateContent.ParseNodes(StackOfFrames stack, List`1 sharedProperties, Int32& nameNumber)
   at System.Windows.TemplateContent.ParseTree(StackOfFrames stack, List`1 sharedProperties, Int32& nameNumber)
   at System.Windows.TemplateContent.ParseXaml()
   at System.Windows.FrameworkTemplate.set_Template(TemplateContent value)
   at System.Windows.Baml2006.WpfSharedBamlSchemaContext.<>c.<Create_BamlProperty_FrameworkTemplate_Template>b__277_0(Object target, Object value)
   at System.Windows.Baml2006.WpfKnownMemberInvoker.SetValue(Object instance, Object value)
   at MS.Internal.Xaml.Runtime.ClrObjectRuntime.SetValue(XamlMember member, Object obj, Object value)
   at MS.Internal.Xaml.Runtime.ClrObjectRuntime.SetValue(Object inst, XamlMember property, Object value)
   at System.Xaml.XamlObjectWriter.SetValue(Object inst, XamlMember property, Object value)
   at System.Xaml.XamlObjectWriter.Logic_ApplyPropertyValue(ObjectWriterContext ctx, XamlMember prop, Object value, Boolean onParent)
   at System.Xaml.XamlObjectWriter.Logic_DoAssignmentToParentProperty(ObjectWriterContext ctx)
   at System.Xaml.XamlObjectWriter.WriteEndMember()
   at System.Xaml.XamlWriter.WriteNode(XamlReader reader)
   at System.Windows.Markup.WpfXamlLoader.TransformNodes(XamlReader xamlReader, XamlObjectWriter xamlWriter, Boolean onlyLoadOneNode, Boolean skipJournaledProperties, Boolean shouldPassLineNumberInfo, IXamlLineInfo xamlLineInfo, IXamlLineInfoConsumer xamlLineInfoConsumer, XamlContextStack`1 stack, IStyleConnector styleConnector)
   at System.Windows.Markup.WpfXamlLoader.Load(XamlReader xamlReader, IXamlObjectWriterFactory writerFactory, Boolean skipJournaledProperties, Object rootObject, XamlObjectWriterSettings settings, Uri baseUri)
   at System.Windows.Markup.WpfXamlLoader.LoadBaml(XamlReader xamlReader, Boolean skipJournaledProperties, Object rootObject, XamlAccessLevel accessLevel, Uri baseUri)
   at System.Windows.Markup.XamlReader.LoadBaml(Stream stream, ParserContext parserContext, Object parent, Boolean closeStream)
   at System.Windows.Application.LoadComponent(Object component, Uri resourceLocator)
```

At the moment, I'm not sure what the root cause of this issue is. It's possible that this issue might not occur in the actual production release, but I thought it would be best to bring this to your attention. 

I would appreciate any guidance or assistance in resolving this issue. 

Thank you for your time and help.

Best regards,
